FIGURES 33–41. Aedeagus of
Lesteva longoelytrata longoelytrata (Goeze)
(33–35: Kandavan (Iran), 36–38: Azish-Tau (Russia), 39–41: Yeniköy, paratype of
L. soror Smetana
(Turkey)): 33, 36, 39—parameral view, 34, 37, 40—lateral view, 35, 38, 41—parameral surface of median lobe of aedeagus. Scale bar: 0.2 mm.

Remarks.
L. soror
was described by Smetana (1967) based on 71 specimens from Western Turkey , Mersin province (Yeniköy, Toros). Smetana (1967) compared his new species with "
L. longelytata Gze.
" based on habitual and aedeagal similarity, and noted that the new species could be distinguished by coloration, by the wider and shorter coarsely punctured elytra, by the less convex eyes, and by the shorter and thicker labial palpi. I have studied thousands of specimens of
L. longoelytrata longoelytrata
from North Africa, Europe and other regions, and observed wide range of variabilities in coloration, punctation, body size and proportions. Therefore, after studying 32 paratypes of
L. soror
from the collection of Prague museum, I have come to the conclusion, that
L. soror
is a junior synonym of the common European subspecies
L. longoelytrata longoelytrata
. Additionally, I prepared the aedeagus of one paratype and its shape is within the range of variability of this subspecies ( Fig. 33−41 ). The aedeagus of
L. longoelytrata longoelytrata
(as aedeagi of other species of the genus
Lesteva
) are weakly sclerotized, so the median lobe can be narrower or wide, parameres may be slightly shorter or longer than the apex of the aedeagus and the median keel on the lobe of aedeagus, which is well defined in dry preparations, may be visiblly wider in cleared preparations. Parameral surfaces of median lobe of aedeagi are given in Fig. 35, 38, 41 .

This is a West Palaearctic subspecies, distributed between N Africa ( Morocco , Algeria ), Orkney Islands , Faroe Islands , Iceland and Great Britain through all Europe and C and N part of European Russia and Caucasus, Turkey , Lebanon , Cyprus , Turkmenia and Iran . For the Caucasus it was recorded as
L. bicolor
and
L. obscurus
by Kolenati (1846) without exact localities, as
L . bicolor
from "...Caucaso et trans illum, Klti" by Hochhuth (1849) , as
L. longelytrata
by Leder (1879) from "Michailowo [now Khashuri in Georgia ]...; Dumanisz [?Dmanisi (=Borgalo), Georgia ]...", and as
L. longelytrata var. dorsalis
by Reitter (1909) from "Araxestale" (? Turkey , Armenia or Azerbaijan ). From Turkey it is known from "Asie Mineure" ( Fauvel, 1874a [= 1874b ]), "Col Soganli, 2 600 m " ( Coiffait 1978 ), Mersin ( Smetana 1967 ), Izmir ( Anlas 2009 ), Gümüşhane ( Bordoni 2010 ), and Afyon and Isparta provinces ( Assing 2013 ). The species was recorded from Lebanon ("Caza Bcharré, Kadicha...; ...Caza Metn, Nabeh Sannin (Jabal Sannine)") by Bordoni (1984) and from "Turcm.[ Turkmenistan ]" by Eppelsheim (1892) . It is here for the first time recorded from Karachay-Cherkessia and Dagestan republics of Russia , Azerbaijan , from several provinces of Turkey ( Bursa , Bolu , Kahramanmaraş , Erzurum , Muş , Ardahan , Şırnak ) and Iran .
